H0.text: The cornea in the eye performs a similar function in vertebrates as stomata—tiny pores on plant leaves—do in plants, permitting the exchange of gases between the external environment and internal cells.

H1.text: The alveoli in the lungs perform a similar function to the stomata of plants, permitting the exchange of gases between air in the environment and cells inside the leaf.

H2.text: The chambers in the heart perform a similar function in vertebrates by permitting the exchange of gases between the external environment and vertebrate cells, analogous to the stomata on plant leaves.

H3.text: The salivary glands in the mouth are the tissue in vertebrates that performs a similar function to stomata, permitting the exchange of gases between air in the environment and cells inside the organism.

A4.text: Oxygen breathed in, diffuses through the walls of the alveoli into the enveloping capillaries and into the circulation, and carbon dioxide diffuses from the blood into the lungs to be breathed out.
